awd_titl_txt: GOALI:  WERF, WRF:   Collaborative Research: Quantifying the Contribution of DBPs to the Toxicity of Wastewaters Purified for Potable Reuse: Which Byproduct Classes Matter?
awd_abstract_narration:
Collaborative Proposal Numbers: 1706154/1706575
PI Names: William Mitch/Michael Plewa 

Increasing populations in arid regions of the US and recent droughts in Texas and California are increasing interest in purifying municipal wastewater as a local, secure supply for drinking water.  A critical roadblock for potable reuse projects is lingering uncertainty among utilities, regulators, and the public regarding the human health impacts of chemicals in the purified wastewater. The National Research Council has indicated that byproducts of water and purified wastewater disinfection (disinfection byproducts or DBPs) are the predominant drivers of human health risks; however, the contribution to toxicity of DBPs as a whole and the relative importance of different DBP classes has not been quantified.  In this project the PIs will quantify the contributions of different DBP classes to the toxicity of disinfected purified wastewaters to determine which classes are the most significant drivers of toxicity. Results from this project will provide critical data to enable regulators to evaluate potable reuse projects and to prioritize chemical contaminant classes (particularly DBPs) for regulatory oversight.

In this project the main hypothesis is that advanced treated municipal wastewaters exhibit lower overall toxicity than conventional drinking waters employing wastewater-impacted (i.e., de facto reuse), or even pristine source waters. To test this hypothesis, the PIs will quantitatively compare the toxicity of a series of representative conventional drinking waters using either pristine or wastewater-impacted source waters with waters associated with potable reuse operations. The comparison will employ quantitative in vitro bioassays targeting a range of relevant endpoints (cytotoxicity, genotoxicity, and oxidative stress).

To quantify the contributions of different DBP classes to the toxicity of disinfected potable reuse waters, the PIs will compare the in vitro bioassay responses of disinfected potable reuse waters to those of deionized water spiked with the concentrations of either all the DBPs measured in these waters, or all of the members of specific DBP classes. DBP research has focused on individual chemical classes (e.g., nitrosamines), with chemists and toxicologists often working separately.  By integrating chemical analysis of a broad range of DBP classes with quantitative toxicology to identify the classes driving toxic responses, the PIs expect that results from this work could transform the approach to DBP research. This work will also address two long-standing questions for DBP research.  First, is the toxicity associated with DBP mixtures additive or is there synergism or antagonism? This question will be answered by comparing the bioassay responses for individual DBP classes against their mixtures. Second, DBP research has focused on low molecular weight species, generally accounting for only ~30-40% of total organic halogen (TOX).  To what extent do high molecular weight DBPs contribute to toxicity?  With disinfectants applied upstream of reverse osmosis (RO) units, potable reuse trains are ideal for answering this question. In addition to the research opportunities afforded to graduate and undergraduate students, a high school science teacher and underrepresented high school student will assist in summer research, with an eye to incorporating this material into the high school curriculum over the following year.

por.por_cntn:
Chlorine disinfection of water is highly effective for reducing consumer exposure to pathogens. However, because chlorine reacts with organic matter in waters to produce an array of potentially carcinogenic byproducts (disinfection byproducts or DBPs), chlorine exposures are moderated to ensure control of pathogens while minimizing exposure to DBPs.  Drinking water utilities are increasingly evaluating the purification of municipal wastewater as a safe and reliable water supply, particularly in drought-prone areas, a practice referred to as "potable reuse". Understandably, treatment trains for potable reuse feature a much higher degree of treatment than conventional drinking water plants. A key question is whether the quality of the water produced by potable reuse trains is comparable to that of conventional drinking water. With respect to chemical contaminants, the National Research Council has indicated that DBPs are chemical constituents of highest concern for potable reuse systems.

Chlorine disinfection of drinking water produces a wide array of halogenated (i.e., chlorine-containing) byproducts, only ~30% of which have been characterized. Of the characterized portion of DBPs, only a subset are currently regulated in drinking water. While DBPs occur in mixtures in chlorinated drinking waters, very few studies have evaluated the toxicity of DBP mixtures. This study evaluated the cytotoxicity of the mixtures of DBPs encountered in chlorine-disinfected conventional drinking waters and potable reuse waters; cytotoxicity is a broad toxicity metric that indicates a reduction in the growth of mammalian cells resulting from a chemical exposure. The results indicate that the toxicity of DBP mixtures is additive across a wide array of DBP chemical classes.  Additivity means that the cytotoxicity of DBP mixtures can be calculated based on the measured concentrations of individual DBPs and the known cytotoxicity of these same DBPs (i.e., we can simply add the effects of the individual DBPs).  The results also indicated that the DBP classes currently regulated (e.g., trihalomethanes) are responsible for a minority of the DBP-associated toxicity in disinfected waters, suggesting that regulators should focus on other, currently unregulated DBP classes.

This project also subjected whole disinfected waters to bioassays for cytotoxicity in order to incorporate the contributions of the ~70% of DBPs that remain uncharacterized. Conducting these assays requires extracting and concentrating the DBPs from large volumes of water (~10 L). Since many DBPs are volatile, they can be lost during this concentration process, although the losses had not previously been quantified. This study demonstrated that nearly all of the known DBPs (regulated or unregulated) are lost during the extraction/concentration protocols currently used.  Accordingly, bioassays actually reflect the toxicity of a fraction of the unknown DBPs which are non-volatile.

This project evaluated a series of conventional drinking waters and potable reuse waters using bioassays to capture the cytotoxicity of the non-volatile, uncharacterized fraction of DBPs. The effects of the known, volatile fraction of DBPs was calculated, based on the now-validated assumption that the toxicity of these DBPs is additive. The results indicated that the cytotoxicity of potable reuse waters were usually lower or at least comparable to that of conventional drinking waters, reflecting the high degree of treatment employed in potable reuse treatment trains. These results suggest the high quality of potable reuse water as a future drinking water supply. The results also indicated that a significant fraction of the cytotoxicity of disinfected waters is associated with the uncharacterized, non-volatile fraction of DBPs, suggesting the need to focus research on the characterization of these byproducts.
